’Cause I couldn’t stand the pain
 And I
 Would be sad if our new love
 Was in vain

This ode to a flowering relationship is out of fear of being hurt. Lennon is afraid to give himself to this new love because he doesn’t want to be hurt like he has before. The pain of love and heartbreak is the strongest pain of all. Also, he doesn’t want to view their relationship in a bad light. He wants confirmation from the girl; he wants her to say that she too, wants a beautiful, mature, dependable relationship. A true love. Not just a whim.

And I
 Would be sad if our new love
 Was in vain

Interestingly enough, the second time this line is sung, Paul’s voice can be heard cracking when he sings “was in vain” on the stereo version of A Hard Day’s Night. However, on the mono version this doesn’t happen.

If I love you too, oh please
 Don’t hurt my pride like her

This line just goes to prove how polite the Beatles were! Throughout their music they have used the word Please at least 92 times!

Times have changed, but these guys were always gentleman!

So I hope you see that I
 Would love to love you

This was the first ballad Lennon ever wrote, even though it was a collaborative piece:

That’s my first attempt to write a ballad proper. That was the precursor to In My Life. It has the same chord sequence as In My Life: D and B minor and E minor, those kinds of things. And it’s semi-autobiographical, but not consciously. It shows that I wrote sentimental love ballads, silly love songs, way back when.

Silly love songs indeed! But we love them!!

If I trust in you, oh please
 Don’t run and hide

This is a type of ballad that was only prevalent in John’s early career. As Paul reminisced:

People tend to forget that John wrote some pretty nice ballads. People tend to think of him as an acerbic wit and aggressive and abrasive, but he did have a very warm side to him really which he didn’t like to show too much in case he got rejected. We wrote If I Fell together but with the emphasis on John because he sang it. It was a nice harmony number, very much a ballad.

In a much similar fashion to “Hard Day’s Night,”“ the lyrics for this song were written on a Valentine’s day card.

’Cause I’ve been in love before
 And I found that love was more
 Than just holding hands

It seems like they’ve grown out of their “holding hands” stage. Just the year before they had released the song “I Wanna Hold Your Hand”.

America loved it! It became their first hit single over here in the states, and it became the perfect schoolboy crush anthem.

If I fell in love with you
 Would you promise to be true
 And help me understand

McCartney was particularly proud of his contribution to this song:

I was a big fan of the preamble in my early days, which you find in lots of ’50s songs. A first verse that goes: ‘I was living in Kentucky when I did, did, did and I dud-dud-dud, and then I said…’ [breathes in deeply]… then you break into the bit of the song you want everyone to know. One song I wrote a little after Please Please Me was my best attempt at a preamble: If I Fell. [Sings] ‘If I fell in love with you, would you promise to be truuue…’ Then after the line, ‘just holding hands’, the song properly gets going. [Raises voice] That’s it, everyone!

The band was always trying to do something more, incorporate something new into everything they did. Their ability to incorporate scores of musical techniques and innovative sounds is what eventually allowed them to capture the hearts of the entire world.
